job_title: Assessment and Reconnection Worker in London, England
pros: Overtime available. Good rate of pay
cons: Long shifts, you need to be invested in genuinely wanting to help rough sleepers. Don't do this for the money

review_title: Meaningful work, impersonal charity to work for, good pay for the sector
job_title: Locum Project Worker in London, England
pros: - good training offered for full time staff - strict adherence to fair procedures and policies - some managers are very good - diligent, flexible, supportive - great fellow staff, supportive teams, people who care about the work - Locum's get the chance to work flexibly (at different places, who all want you to work full time there for a good stretch of time, as they basically need cover for absence of full-time staff in the roles) - opportunity to gain lots of varied experience as clients are very diverse. - meaningful work based on keyworker/client working relationships - senior managers (regional level) were very competent, supportive, professional, approachable
cons: - Locum staff not offered as much training as full-time Project Workers even though I was doing the same work - Some line managers are sub par and disinterested and I had to chase them for support, it felt like they did the bare minimum - some hostels are unpleasant places to work as they feel so institutional, can feel like a cog in a broken homeless support system. - 4 x 12h shifts a week and hard work meant work/life balance was difficult to achieve. My rota was not regular on a weekly basis so could not schedule regular personal hobbies/activities. - I found it hard to navigate the online system through which I applied for different work. they were in the process of changing systems at the time.

pros: Making a difference and empowering people to acquire skills to help them live a more fulfilling life and live independently.
cons: Very stressful job. It may drain you psychologically.

pros: I could easily save some money for my holiday post Covid pandemic lockdown. I could get the job easily without having the necessary skills for it.
cons: I could not assist vulnerable clients appropriately and always had to report to managers on what to do. I was unable to fix situations and users suffered abuser, neglect and failure in safeguarding out of it. The little training I was given was not enough to suffice the demands of forensic and complex needs clients. I left the job as in no way it is a job a person should just put themselves into without relevant qualification and extensive experience.

pros: The staff at St Mungo's are great. Client facing teams really care about their clients and will go above and beyond to do the right thing for them. Our services have a very positive impact on people's lives, but this wouldn't be the case without the people running them. It is so rewarding seeing the positive changes in client's lives. I've always worked with friendly colleagues and had supportive managers, and enjoyed working with other people in different teams.
cons: Several years ago I rated St Mungo's 5 stars but my rating has decreased to 2 stars due to the disconnection between the board and CEO with the rest of the organisation. The appointment of the new CEO is incredibly controversial and communications from senior leadership to staff seem clueless about this. Staff are feeling under pressure and frustrated, with the cost of living crisis exacerbating things.

job_title: Night Assessment Worker in London, England
pros: Opportunities to develop and grow, with management supporting us in taking specialised trainings. Due to the nature of the work some shifts would be challenging but my team was very supportive. I really enjoyed my time working here.
cons: Your quality of work-life is very dependent on your team, especially as night workers work in shifts of 3. Was worried about the long term health effects of disrupting my circadian rhythm regularly but this might not be an issue for some.

pros: The interview process and training seemed great
cons: Was basically told not to return after my first day due to my mental illness as the job wouldn’t be suitable for me. I was also called aggressive and told to lower my tone when I wasn’t even being remotely aggressive. Someone tried to correct me on something and was wrong so I told them they were wrong and was told off even though they interrupted me.

job_title: Assessment and Reconnection Worker in London, England
pros: Friendly teams Lots of progression available
cons: Remote head office and senior management Increasingly corporate

job_title: Night reconnection assistant  in London, England
pros: The pay was fine, considering it was my first job after Uni
cons: The job is demanding, working with clients has a toll on you

pros: Great clients to work with
cons: Too much pay disparity between execs and frontline stagf

pros: Toil/ Flexi working Colleagues Lots of documented policies
cons: Central services often unhelpful Senior management out of touch No boundaries for clients, they are treated like children and not expected to have any responsibility whatsoever

pros: People and holiday pay are great
cons: Salary isn't very high for the work you do

review_title: Could be worse, could be better
job_title: Assessment and Reconnection Worker in London, England
pros: Flexi time and opportunities to move internally
cons: IT and the divide between frontline staff and head office Clients tend to hate the organization

review_title: Not enough support to meet demand
pros: Salary colleagues clients training experience
cons: CEO and board are out of touch with the situation of the workers Local authorities expect too much for too little burn out rate is increasing again high staff turn over and rising

job_title: Assessment and Reconnection Worker in London, England
pros: - Fair pay for the sector - Good training opportunities and further development - Good scope for lateral moves - Active Diversity networks
cons: - Long hours, sometimes insufficient use of time and funds - Frontline role working with vulnerable clients - can be stressful if their is not a good team around you - Very incremental salary rise

pros: Great cause to work for
cons: Evidence of a bullying culture

pros: Very pro union Doing great work
cons: Pay could be better Long hours

review_title: Good place to work - lots of HR
pros: People are really nice and the general atmosphere is good
cons: There seems to be a lot of box-ticking HR practices that can feel not genuine

job_title: Internal Communications Officer in London, England
pros: Support for your wellbeing Good management Supportive working environment
cons: Recent high turnover due to salary disputes

pros: Good Team when the old team was there
cons: Not all staff signing from the same hymn sheet

pros: Great exposure to HR as an entry level role. Very inclusive recruitment process and open to all backgrounds as long as you have admin experience
cons: Not a con per se, the work is high volume - however it’s a great deep dive into HR and I learnt a lot!

job_title: Recovery College Coordinator in London, England
pros: Great people who really care about clients
cons: Senior management could communicate better

job_title: Skills and Employment Advisor in London, England

pros: Lots of progression chances Motivated, driven colleagues. Rewarding work
cons: Contracts are determined by local authorities, often changing every 3-5 years, so projects are regularly closing, opening or changing. Budgets are always tight. Lack of cohesion - 300ish different services

pros: A charity that really lives its values. Pay is pretty good for the sector, flexible working
cons: Can be difficult to get a promotion

pros: Lots of learn and great people
cons: Can be stressful, bad management

pros: Great colleagues and sense of purpose
cons: Tough working conditions and hours

pros:

Toil to gain extra days off.

The role is similar to others in the service but this one pays a lot less.

job_title: Street Outreach Worker in Poplar, England
pros: Supportive, good development, large organisation for move on ops
cons: Shift work and demanding but still rewarding

review_title: I wouldn't return to St mungos
pros:
The people who work front line at St mungos that I met are dynamic and smart people who care about the cause. 
The money good 
You can move up more easily now than you could before
cons: Work life balance isn't great. I think mungos agree to take on work and they don't think about the staff wellbeing in all of this extra work. I think the safety of staff comes last. If you make a mistake at work you are in deep trouble for it where as we were meant to forgive clients for everything.

pros: st mungos are good employer
cons: shift hours are really hard

review_title: It's okay - good exposure to the third sector
pros:
Strong focus on EDI initiatives
Driven to provide meaningful face to face work (Outreach/Services)
cons:
Very large organisation 
Culture varies from team to team
Not enough people from minority groups represented in leadership and or management roles especially in head office.

pros: flexible working and committed staff
cons: punitive sickness policy here at mungos

pros:
Supportive management team
Workers wanting to do a good job 
Good client involvement 
EDI initiatives
Reasonable salary s and T&Cs
Psychologically Informed Environments in some services
cons:
High risk clients and lack of clinical interventions 
In some projects low standard of decor & furnishings 
Local authority funding cuts impacting on service delivery
Need to go above & beyond if you want to make a difference
Heavy workload

pros: Excellent workplace and good team camaraderie.
cons: Quite a small organization but doing a lot.

pros: Good thing about a big organization is really good policies and loads of internal teams, helps you feel supported
cons: No where in charity sector pays that well I suppose

pros:
Fast paced, interesting person centred work- never boring 
Decent, competitive pay 
Opportunities and training available for progression/ development within the organisation or sector 
Certain jobs accessible to applicants without lots of experience- transferable skills and can-do attitude are considered at interview
cons: Many barriers are faced by the client group. Sector wide pressure on available resources means it can take lots of advocacy by St Mungo’s for the right outcomes to be achieved to improve people’s lives

pros:
Room for progression into other roles within the company. 
Experience of working in diverse communities with a range of clients. 
Pay is decent but can be higher in other companies.
cons:
Pay is higher in other companies. 
Clients are placed higher than the welfare of staff. 
Can become stagnant in role as managers can be too busy with their own workload. 
Unable to do vital work with clients as majority of role is working reception. 
More admin based than actually working with clients.

pros:
Colleague support and connection 

Diversity networks
cons: Lack of support from senior management

job_title: Rough Sleepers Services Coordinaotr in London, England

- Motivated workforce with sincere reasons for joining
- Endless training opportunities
- Excellent shadowing
- Good opportunities
cons: - Can be a bit top heavy at the top of the organisation, with question marks over salary increases for the CEO and executive committee, all the while some services lack proper facilities and renovation

review_title: No longer a great company to work for
pros:
Great staff for networking and connecting with. 
Flexible working for certain teams
Laid back work for certain teams
Easy going for certain people and management
cons:
Long referencing processes
Too many  heads
No clear for the future only about money driven targets
More of a business than a charity or housing association 
Over buying services and not contributing more time to current sites and staff
Unprofessional head office teams and too much politics
No correct policies in place
Out of date IT systems and strategies
Small finance team
No manager support
Not at all diverse
Too much paper work
Too much work load no time to support staff

review_title: One of the better companies in the sector
pros: Matured over the years and has lots of policies and procedures and generally support their workers
cons: Central teams are sometimes unhelpful and/or lacking knowledge skills.

pros:
Rewarding.
Help empower vulnerable individuals and support them in bettering their lives. 
Good training and development opportunities.
Client focused .
cons:
Staff wellbeing not prioritised enough.
Racism imbedded in organisation.
Low pay rate for front line workers, compared to those in corporate.

pros: Good salary , commuted staff
cons: High caseload not enough time in working week to meet this

pros: large company with lots os support
cons: none i can think of

pros: Great team to work with for energy
cons: Highly demanding, constantly battling role

pros:
Great, cohesive team
Chance to work with some incredibly inspiring clients

review_title: If you work hard they will notice
job_title: Agency Support Worker in Bristol, England
pros: Once on salary, they pay well. There are plenty of progression opportunities if you work hard. They offer training. The people are lovely.
cons: If you are an agency worker, the training isn't there. In my limited experience, the management could be better.

pros: The role was well paid in comparison with other similar jobs and employers
cons: Not supportive of their own staffs difficulties, lives, and personal circumstances. Uncaring and have literally ignored staff in crisis. Managers admit to a positive discrimination attitude but won't speak up. Managers abuse authority and are not honest and transparent in recording interactions with staff, nor do they treat all staff fairly. Management contact staff during their annual leave about work matters

pros: Plenty of career growth options, rewarding work
cons: Deep rooted and long standing bullying/harassment issues, extremely strict and unfair sickness policies, anti-union culture perpetuated by senior management

review_title: Good Benefits, experience varies on location
pros:
Reasonable-good pay, 
Opportunities to transfer into other roles,
Extensive training
cons:
Experience varies on where you work.
Some managers have a bad rep, whilst others are more grounded.

review_title: Challenging role with endless learning, and great growth opportunities, but a high stress role.
pros:
Hands on role, demanding creativity and personal approach.
Supportive colleagues and a social atmosphere.
Excellent growth opportunities and high rate of staff promotions.
Competency based approach to staff.
Working with people directly, building up strong working relationships with residents and being able to provide practical support.
cons:
High stress role, often handling emotionally challenging incidents such as self-harm, overdoses and physical fights. 
Poor work life balance. Differs service to service but rota style can lead to staff burn-out.
Management can sometimes feel distant from the work we do due to the high demands that they face in their roles, too.

pros:
Good pay 
Flexible work - hours & location
Good management
cons: No cons as of yet

Good progression routes
cons:
Difficult to assess at this stage but will write more and update later on..
Pressures of working in CQC registered environments and generally the lack of funding that comes from central government

pros: Great job amazing team and good experience

job_title: Human Resources Administrator in London, England
pros: friendly team, diverse work, very ethical
cons: over worked, long hours, micro management

pros: large and plenty of opps
cons: third sector - low salaries

pros: Extremely rewarding work when you're allowed to get on with it. Wonderful service users, some amazing colleagues. Used to provide very good training. Salaries are good.
cons: Various HR and other systems that are very rigid and punitive which take control away from frontline managers. The problem being HR are not the experts in supporting the vulnerable service users and managers are consumed with having to respond to reports and data entry rather than developing and supporting their staff. St Mungos used to value diversity not just in terms of ethnicity and gender etc but in terms of life experience and ability to work with the client group and challenging the status quo. Now it seems to place value on people keeping their opinions to themselves and accepting orders from HQ.

pros:
Staff development 
Management listen
Diversity networks 
Career development
Supportive Colleagues
Workwhile work
Large range or opportunities 
Pay is good enough to keep you in the sector
cons:
Still some divide between former Broadway and old Mungos employees and ways if doing things
Difficult when workers are teepeed across to or from other services
The work itself can be challenging and the warnings approach can be counterproductive.
Can feel a bit bureaucratic in terms of the online system though I recognise stats and records are necessary for commissioners and donors.

pros: It can really nice working with clients. There is a lot of training, some of which is good and some not so good.
cons: High stress job with heavy workload. There is a clear hierarchy with strong directives coming from the top. Staff are heavily monitored and it can feel a bit like school with constant supervision, appraisals and case all overs.  There appears to be a high turnover and they are employing more career minded people rather than client focused individuals. There is a also a lot of pointless staff consultations as the executive directors just do what they want regardless.

pros: Dedicated and skillful on the ground workers, valuable work with clients.
cons:
Limited autonomy at work. Very little support and sympathy/empathy for staff following an incident - almost a blame culture e.g. what did you do to provoke it? You're expected to have a high tolerance for harassment and abuse from clients. Majority of managers have very little regard for staff wellbeing and you're expected to move on from things - all this eventually leading to regular burnout and high turnover of staff.
There is very little diversity in management. Very top down approach to charity work. It is the funders who decide the work that is done, rather than the client or staff on the ground.

review_title: St Mungo's is a safe bet to continue bringing equality and diversity about.
pros: Great group of women in our all womens project including clients.
cons: The client centred ethos is primarily but we shouldn't overlook the fact that...without the voluntary sector and the staff we wouldn't have enough hands on approach for the client and this chaotic behaviour can be copied and mimicked as dysfunctional.

pros: Inclusive environment which promote diversity and inclusion at all levels. Great progression and internal development. Best organisations I have worked for to date and friendly senior leadership team. So much to do internally inside and outside main job and a culture of positivity and desire to help client group. Loved it.
cons: Not much progression for those with interest outside of frontline work. So those in specialist areas have no choice but to leave for progression. Great place to work nonetheless.

pros: A friendly and professional organisation helping to meet the needs of the mist vulnerable in our society, seeing them on to new pathways to sustainable society integration.
cons: Overly focused on the needs of the client group to the detriment of staff, albeit none intended. Very emotionally draining to deal with the extreme ends of human nature.

job_title: Deputy Project Manager in London, England
pros: Working with some of the most vulnerable people in our society and supporting them to make meaningful, positive changes in their life
cons: Lack of support for frontline staff: a “get on with it” attitude to danger/risk/lack of resources. Hostels frequently lack the bare necessities (furniture) yet head office is state of the art/luxury.

pros: Met some really good people .Teams are really joy to work in.Lots of leisure time and working / helping clients is good.
cons: Bureaucracy set in when people are employed who don't actually care about people.Regimented policies and archaic procedures hamper common sense.

job_title: Head of Drug and Alcohol Services/Complex Needs Manager in London, England
pros:
I felt uniquely prized and valued
the work is very socially important
the organisation is forward looking
their client involvement is excellent
my colleagues are very dedicated and go to any lengths to be helpful
cons:
the pressures on public budgets undermined good services
the unsatisfactory performance of other agencies imposed unsustainable burdens on our services
the budgetary processes of commissioners imposed unrealistic funding horizons on the work, preventing  sustained continuous improvement

review_title: The practice is far from the Ethos in tackling homelessness
pros: Support of the most disatvantages client group.  Amazing front line workers
cons: The charity is sadly more focused in it own financial growth. It's a  Modern dictatorship and less focus on the conditions of the service . The policies do not support staff wellbeing and growth

review_title: Awful support from HR and management
pros: Some clients and colleagues are really great.
cons:
No support given to those who are affected by the traumatic experiences with clients.

Extreme lack of safety concerns, working with some very dangerous people however still expected to work alone with clients. 

St Mungo's work puts the local community in danger by placing people with very complex needs in building with families. 

HR system is awful and punitive for those who are ill.

High targets need to be met which encourages staff to house clients in unsuitable properties.

pros:
Excellent training with personalised career coaching 
Very rewarding sector to work in 
Recognition of individual potential and development encouraged
cons: Senior / Executive Diversity Needs to improve - Slow steps are being taken towards this and the board of trustees  is slightly more diverse than it was 18 months ago.

review_title: A great employer with great values.
pros:
There are great development opportunities for employees, and I have felt valued from day one.
The organisation has clearly-defined values, which - for the most part - it lives up to.
cons: I have been extremely lucky to have had a positive experience throughout my time at St Mungo's, so I would be hard pushed to list any real cons.

job_title: Project Worker in Kings Cross, England
pros: Very rewarding regarding it being client based and focused. Supervisions are productive and very much needed.
cons: Burn out due to client's levels of physical and verbal abuse, high turnover with staff. The cleaner went back to Poland after one clients criminal charges against her. Support or not it takes it's toll on a person.

pros: The are an organisation who really care about their mission to help with homelessness. They are brilliant with client involvement, and at coming up with innovative solutions to help with homelessness. There is a very strong work ethic, and lots of intelligent people working for the organisation.
cons: Some people think the recruitment process is a little OTT, but I think it is good.

review_title: Overall great, and continuing to improve

cons: Very slow systems can make it hard for you to do your job; very high workload a lot of the time; changes take a long time (often due to very bureaucratic processes); inconsistent experience of management across the organisation
